bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, November 24, 1942

div1.p: Hench makes recommendations for some corrections and possible deletions from Truby's manuscript. He encourages him to take steps to have the book published sooner rather than later.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, November 24, 1942
div1.opener:
STATION HOSPITAL
Camp Carson, Colorado
November 24, 1942
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Although I have read your manuscript three or four times in
the past, I once more got quite a thrill reading it again. I have
very few suggestions to make. I am like you, I hate to see any of
the photographs omitted, but if necessary, and I am afraid it will be
necessary, I would agree with you to omit photographs 2, 6, 7, 13,
23, 24, 35, 38, and 40. If necessary I would suggest six more that
might be omitted: photographs 3, 5, 12, 22, 42, and 44. Photograph
3 must be of considerable interest to you, but it would be of less
interest to your readers, especially those chiefly interested in the
Cuban phase of your life. Photograph 5, if I might say so, is not
a very good photograph; the trees are cut off and there is much too
much foreground. If you want to include this, I would suggest that
you have it printed enlarged so as to bring out the figures of the
horses and men and then cut of the foreground. But I really do be-
lieve it is not a very good picture. Photograph 12 is also none too
good for reproductive purposes and I suspect that the publishers
would suggest omitting it. Photograph 22 is not actually a part of
the story, perhaps it could be omitted. Photograph 42 - somewhere
I have seen a photograph of this mosquito cage in actual use with a
bed and patient inside the cage. If you have seen such a photograph,
it would be better then this. Photograph 44 - this table could of
course be set up in type and not used as a photograph and that would
save money.

Incidentally, on photograph 19 at the bottom the work
“marianao” is spelled wrong.

I am only concerned about two things: You claim that photo-
graph 30 is of the Surggry Second Division Hospital and that this
Surgery later became Walter Reed's Laboratory. You will remember that
in my previous correspondence, I pointed out the directions of this
building in connection with General Lee's headquarters which shows
up on the original of this large photograph from which you have cut
out the photograph of the Surgery. If one studies the relationship
-2-
of the maps to the little building which you call the Surgery, this
either is not the surgery or it must have been moved; it could not be
the Surgery and bear the relationship to General Lee's headquarters
which appear in the photographs as checked by the maps. It is your
opinion that the Surgery must have been moved. It is a little diffi-
cult to accept this explanation. We have hundreds of buildings around
here that are exactly the same. Is it not possible that this building
resembles or is almost identical with Walter Reed's Laboratory but is
not actually the latter. Secondly, it is difficult for me to believe
that they would have gone to the trouble of putting a building on
wheels and moving it. I just can't believe that that is Walter Reed's
Laboratory.

The second point with which I cannot agree is where you insist
in your footnote to page 102 that the New York Academy of Medicine
Laboratory Book “contains the handwriting of Reed, Lezear, and Neate”.
I have been over this book scores of times and have a copy of abso-
lutely everything in it. Ninety-nine per cent of the writing is that
of Lezear and Reed; there are only one or two little scratch notes in
unidentifiable handwriting and these were merely little pieces of paper
lying loose in the notebook. It is possible that they may be in Neate's
handwriting but nobody knows for sure. I am sure that even General
Russell who presumably identifies the hand as that of Neate is wrong
and that he would agree he is wrong if he could see Lezear's and Redd's
handwriting with that which I have of Neate'sthem. I would suggest that
you change the note to read “with notes in the handwriting of Lezear
and Reed. I put the names in that order because that is the order
the handwriting appears in the notebook. Whatever you decide to do
about these two points is of course your privilege. They are the only
two points which disturb me.

I think the book will look swell in printing and I encourage
you to let it be published at once. I don't want to be Macabre but I
am so anxious that you see this book and enjoy the reaction of the
readers and, after all, you are getting along in years. Practically
all publishers offer ten per cent royalty. I will admit that I be-
lieve at times this is ten per cent of the retail price and they are
offering you ten per cent of the wholesale price, but maybe this is
the usual arrangement. At any rate I would urge you to accept it.
While you would like to make a little money on it, your main satisfac-
tion will come from seeing the book in print and the material on the
on the record and of receiving the reaction of the readers to it.
Naturally you would like to get enough money to cover the expenses
of typing, etc., but everything else is subsidiary to the importance
of having the matter printed and in the records. I warn you that
-3-
some literary minded critics may criticize the literary style of the
book; critics have to do that, but you will not be disturbed by a few
harsh voices and I know you will be very gratified at the reception
which it will receive at the hands of your colleagues, friends, and
the medical public. I have never seen a book yet, even the best,
that did not receive some bad criticism.

I am expressing the manuscript as you have directed and will
properly insure it. Naturally, I will not let you pay for the trifling
expense that I have had - it was worth very much more than that for
me to read the manuscript and to have the pleasure of being connected
with your work in some way. Your autograph on one copy will more
than repay me for whatever trouble I might have gone to. I will want
to buy a number of copies and only wish that the book will be out by
Christmas.

I am very busy here and my experiences in the Army Medical
Corps have added to my appreciation of your book, because I can now
compare the Medical Corps' work of your day and how it now works.
I am snowed under with paper work and the amount of medical work
that I can do is almost nil. This disappoints me greatly but this
apparently cannot be changed. Please keep me informed as to the
progress of the book.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, P. S. HENCH Lieut Colonel, M.C.
